docTitle.titlePart: Overpopulation and Birth Control in India

sourceDesc.bibl: "Over-Population and Birth Control: MRS.SANGER's VIEWS", The Times of India, Jan 23 1936

doc.headNote: Sanger spoke at the Town Hallof Hyderabad, India on Jan 23, 1936, and this summary was released to a number of Indian papers including Times of India, The Hindu and Bombay Chronicle.

div.p: “The problem of over-population has been extremely acute all over the world vis-a-vis the social and economic conditions of the people today. Starvation, unemployment, and high infant and maternity mortality are a few of its baleful results,” said Mrs. Margaret Sanger, who is on a brief visit to Hyderabad, in the course of a lecture at the Town Hall, last evening.
She added: “The practice of birth control offers the only sure way out of this-the one hope for the youth of the future - and the only sure solvent of most social and economic ills everywhere.”

Mrs. Sanger, continuing, said that high medical and other authorities now lent the prestige of their names to the movement, which had hitherto been left in obscurity and treated as highly controversial. Today emigration had ceased to provide an escape from the problem of over population. Only two alternatives remained, namely, death - Nature’s method of birth control- and birth control proper. “To say that birth control means murder is to speak without knowledge of facts. It is merely prevention of conception of life. How then can the question of murder arise.”

p.q: Proceeding, Mrs. Sanger contrasted the conditions of masses all over the world, where large and unlimited families were creating legacies in slums increasing unemployment, ignorance, starvation, misery and death, with conditions under birth control, where families would be regulated with regard to three important factors, the health of the mother, the income of the father and the standard of living of the family.

div.p: “In the former group,” said Mrs. Sanger,“every social problem is daily increasing whereas in the latter the very opposite would be the result.”

p.q: In conclusion Mrs. Sanger said that Indiahad her problem of overpopulation the same as the rest of the world, though slightly in a greater degree, since infant and maternity mortality statistics in India were slightly higher than anywhere else in the world. it was therefore up to them to ponder over the situation and apply the only remedy which showed the way to improved health and better standard of living of the family community in the country.
